Living in a fast-paced city like Hong Kong, it can be easy to get caught up in work and daily responsibilities, neglecting our mental and emotional wellbeing. As we age, it is natural to reflect on our lives and contemplate the choices we have made. As a result, some people in their retirement years look back on their lives with regret and remorse, realizing that they have neglected to cherish their limited time, pursued their dreams, spent time with family and friends, and repaired damaged relationships. They carry the burden of self-blame for the past and anxiety about the future, unable to enjoy the present moment or recognize the significance of their lives.

For many of us, Since most of the elders are affected by Chinese culture, they struggle to communicate their emotions and expressing our true feelings and emotions can be challenging, especially due to cultural influences that discourage direct communication. For exmplae many elders may find it difficult to express their thoughts and feelings directly to those around them, such as saying "I love you," "I'm sorry," "Goodbye," or "Thank you." Furthermore, death is a taboo topic in Chinese culture, even though it is an inevitable stage of life and Elders may also find it difficult to face the inevitability of death, leading to fear and avoidance. However, we need to prepare for them to accept death, it about important to acknowledge that death is a natural part of life

we can Help elders to reflect on life experiences and find meaning and purpose. For older adults, this can be an opportunity to make peace with past regrets and to strengthen relationships with loved ones. By preparing for the end of life, we can help elders find peace of mind and ensure that our final wishes are fulfilled.
